results.title: Fantasy of feet
results.creator_credit: Frederic Goodich, Warren Brown and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows scenes of feet walking, dancing, running, and jumping, barefooted and in sandals, flippers, slippers and boots to encourage children to think about the different kinds of shoes and how feet serve their many functions. Suitable for upper primary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frederic Goodich, Warren Brown and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Fantasy man
results.creator_credit: John Meagher, Basil Appleby, Darrell Lass and Centaur Enterprises
results.brief_description: Mid-life crisis, bored with work, his wife and his life, Nick Bailey (Harold Hopkins) begins to fantasize about the young and rather attractive Donna (Kerry Mack), who works at the hamburger stand near his office. Nick’s wife Liz (Jeanie Drynan) confused and disturbed by Nick’s strange and secretive behaviour, especially his long showers, finds herself fantasizing about a former lover after a chance meeting. Can their marriage survive? Does anyone care? A low-budget film with a pretty ordinary plot. Cast also features Kate Fitzpatrick.

results.title: Fantasia 2000
results.creator_credit: Don Hahn, Eric Goldberg, Francis Glebas, Gaetan Brizzi, Hendel Butoy, James Algar, Paul Brizzi, Pixote Hunt, Donald W. Ernst and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Presented by Walt Disney’s nephew Roy E. Disney, “Fantasia 2000” is a realisation of Walt’s dream to reissue his marriage of music and animation that was “Fantasia” (1940). The brief introduction also covers Disney milestones in animation innovation. “Fantasia” was a grand experiment in film-making, a concert film and homage to animation. Stylistically speaking, it prescribed the use of Fantasound which included 64 speakers. Disney originally intended the film to be periodically re-released with the inclusion of new scenes; due to poor audience response and various other factors, this wish never eventuated - until now. Shot on Imax by seven directors (Pixote Hunt, Hendel Butoy, Eric Goldberg, James Algar, Francis Glebas, Gaetan and Paul Brizzi, Don Hahn), “Fantasia 2000” presents seven new segments and only one carry over scene from the original - Mickey Mouse in “The Sorcerer’s apprentice.” This new interpretation of music from composers such as Beethoven, Respighi, Gershwin, Shostakovich and Stavinsky received mixed reviews from critics who thought it did not match the continuity of style of the original or the substance. Steve Martin, Bette Midler, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury and Quincy Jones are just a few of the big names who introduce each segment. The Chicago Symphony Orchestra is conducted by James Levine.

results.title: Family down the Fraser
results.creator_credit: Tony Westman, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Richard and Rochelle Wright and their two sons travelled the Fraser River from Cache Tete Jaune to the Pacific coast in a rubber raft. In addition to being a great adventure, the trip brought them into contact with people who told them some of the history of the river, and acquainted them with lifestyles vastly different from their own citified ways.

results.title: Family day care [Greek version]
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Designed to describe all aspects of the family Day Care Scheme, financed by the Department of Social Security, the film follows a co-ordinator of a scheme in the inner Sydney suburb Marackville. Through her day-to-day experiences we see different kinds of care being given to children’s differing needs and we see colourful experiences designed for the children by highly skilled care-givers. Cinematography by John Hosking. In Greek and English.

results.title: Fair treatment
results.creator_credit: Tim Johnson, Chris McGill and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: This program examines some of the most important issues facing people living with HIV and contains interviews with people who are HIV positive. It focuses on the availability of drugs for HIV patients, and the lack of action and apathy shown by Australian governments. It also explores the outlook on life of the interviewees, how the stigma of AIDS, the death of friends and loved ones has affected them and finally examines their attitudes to death and dying.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Johnson, Chris McGill and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: Fairy tale: a true story
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Bruce Davey, Wendy Finerman and Anna K Productions
results.brief_description: In 1917 two English girls, Elise Wright and Frances Griffiths photographed fairies in their garden. These photographs became known as the Cottingley photographs, eponymous from the village where the girls lived. This led to the often asked question, “do fairies exist?”. This event led to a nation wide search for the truth, led by two personalities of the day, Harry Houdini (Harvey Keitel), and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (Peter O’Toole). Although this film is based on a true event; the existence of the photographs, the film’s ending does differ from the truth that eventuated much later. A magical tale that will enchant viewers of all ages. Cast includes Florence Hoath, Elizabeth Earl, Paul McGann and Phoebe Nicholls.

results.title: Fair play
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australian women cricketers are the undisputed world-cup cricket champions in a sport which is hotly contested by nine affiliated countries. This film follows their latest tour to England to play on the hallowed grounds at Lords.

results.title: Fahrenheit 9/11
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Jim Czarnecki, Kathleen Glynn, Dog Eat Dog Films, IFC Productions (US), Lions Gate Films and The Fellowship Adventure Group
results.brief_description: The heat is up in this award-winning documentary made by maverick dissident Michael Moore (“Bowling for Columbine”) with his sharp wit and biting commentary on the United States’ Government and contemporary America. President George W. Bush bares the brunt of this filmmaker’s wrath as Moore, with his sense of humour intact, sets about to make clear to the world American foreign policy and its consequences. This is the sort of filmmaking that gets people thinking, talking and hopefully, taking action. Not only did “Fahrenheit 9/11” win awards but its popularity with the cinema-going public created a record at the box office for a documentary film and paved the way for other works in the genre to be more prominent in the cinema exhibition market. Winner of Best Picture at Cannes 2004.
